title: Quiz 22: Orthopedic Nursing
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions

questions.question: A patient with a displaced femoral neck fracture is scheduled for surgical intervention. Which surgical procedure is most appropriate for this type of fracture?
questions.explanation: ORIF involves surgically exposing the fracture site to align the bone fragments (reduction) and fixing them with hardware (screws/plates). It is standard for displaced fractures requiring stability.
questions.hint: Since the fracture is 'displaced' and in the hip (femoral neck), simply pulling it back in place (closed) is often insufficient; surgery to open and fix it is needed.

questions.question: A patient presents with a Colles' fracture. What is the characteristic deformity associated with this type of fracture?

options.text: Dorsal displacement of the distal fragment
Ventral displacement of the distal fragment
Lateral displacement of the distal fragment
Medial displacement of the distal fragment

questions.explanation: A Colles' fracture is a distal radius fracture with dorsal (backward) displacement of the wrist, creating the classic 'dinner fork' deformity.
questions.hint: Think of the shape of a dinner fork faced down.

richContent.content:
Fracture Types:
  • Colles': Dorsal displacement (Dinner fork)
  • Smith's: Volar/Ventral displacement (Garden spade)

questions.question: Which imaging modality is most commonly used to diagnose fractures of the long bones, such as the femur or tibia?
questions.explanation: Plain radiographs (X-rays) are the first-line and most cost-effective diagnostic tool for assessing bony structures and fractures.
questions.hint: The standard first test for any broken bone.

questions.question: A patient with osteoarthritis of the knee experiences persistent pain and functional limitation despite conservative management. Which surgical procedure is commonly performed to alleviate symptoms and improve function in such cases?
questions.explanation: Total Knee Arthroplasty (TKA) involves replacing the damaged joint surfaces with artificial components. It is the definitive treatment for advanced osteoarthritis when other methods fail.
questions.hint: When the joint is worn out and medication doesn't work, the joint is often replaced.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with long-term use of corticosteroids in orthopedic patients?
questions.explanation: Corticosteroids inhibit osteoblast function (bone formation) and increase bone resorption, leading to significant bone density loss (Osteoporosis).
questions.hint: Steroids make bones brittle over time.

questions.question: A patient presents with a displaced fracture of the distal radius and ulna after a fall. What is the preferred initial treatment for this injury?
questions.explanation: Initial management involves realigning the bones (closed reduction) and applying a splint to immobilize the area while allowing for acute swelling.
questions.hint: Fix the alignment first without cutting the skin, then protect it while swelling goes down.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by inflammation of the tendons surrounding the shoulder joint, leading to pain and restricted movement?
questions.explanation: While 'tear' implies structural damage, the question describes inflammation of tendons, which is Rotator Cuff Tendinitis. Among the options, Rotator Cuff pathology is the correct anatomical answer.
questions.hint: Focus on the anatomy: 'tendons surrounding the shoulder'.

questions.question: A patient presents with acute knee pain and swelling following a twisting injury during sports activity. Physical examination reveals joint effusion and tenderness along the joint line. Which structure is most likely injured in this scenario?
questions.explanation: The classic triad for a meniscal tear is: 1) Twisting injury, 2) Joint line tenderness, and 3) Delayed effusion (swelling).
questions.hint: Tenderness specifically 'along the joint line' is the hallmark of this cartilage injury.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by inflammation of the plantar fascia, resulting in heel pain that is typically worse with the first steps in the morning?
questions.explanation: Plantar fasciitis causes pain on the bottom of the heel, famously described as 'first-step pain' in the morning or after rest.
questions.hint: Pain on the bottom of the foot when you first wake up.

questions.question: A patient presents with knee pain and instability following a twisting injury during sports activity. MRI reveals a tear involving the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL). Which surgical procedure is commonly performed to reconstruct the ACL?
questions.explanation: The procedure is named after the ligament it repairs: ACL Reconstruction.
questions.hint: The answer is in the name of the injured ligament.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with untreated clubfoot in infants?
questions.explanation: There is a known association between congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) and developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH).
questions.hint: Check the hips when you see clubfoot.

questions.question: A patient presents with chronic low back pain and radicular symptoms radiating down the leg. MRI reveals a herniated disc at the L5-S1 level with compression of the adjacent nerve root. Which surgical procedure is commonly performed to decompress the nerve root?
questions.explanation: A discectomy involves removing the portion of the herniated disc material that is pressing on the nerve root to relieve pain and compression.
questions.hint: Removal of the disc material itself.

questions.question: Which of the following is a surgical procedure commonly performed to treat carpal tunnel syndrome?
questions.explanation: Carpal tunnel release involves cutting the transverse carpal ligament to release pressure on the median nerve.
questions.hint: The nerve compressed in Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is the Median nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with hip fracture in elderly patients?

options.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.explanation: Displaced fractures of the femoral neck often disrupt the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to bone death (avascular necrosis).
questions.hint: The blood supply to the ball of the hip joint gets cut off.

questions.question: A patient with a tibial shaft fracture undergoes surgical fixation with an intramedullary nail. What postoperative complication should the healthcare team monitor for in the immediate postoperative period?
questions.explanation: The tibia is the most common site for compartment syndrome, a surgical emergency where pressure builds up within muscle compartments, cutting off blood flow.
questions.hint: Pressure buildup in the leg muscles that can kill the tissue.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common clinical manifestation of osteoarthritis in the hip joint?
questions.explanation: Trendelenburg gait is a waddling walk caused by weakness of the hip abductor muscles (gluteus medius), common in hip OA.
questions.hint: A specific type of gait caused by weak hip muscles.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common cause of secondary osteoporosis?
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis (and the steroids often used to treat it) is a major cause of secondary bone loss/osteoporosis.
questions.hint: An autoimmune joint disease that leads to bone loss.

questions.question: A patient presents with acute onset of shoulder pain and limited range of motion after a fall onto an outstretched hand. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus and pain with passive abduction and external rotation. Which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.explanation: The mechanism (FOOSH) combined with specific pain during abduction and external rotation points to injury of the Rotator Cuff (specifically Supraspinatus/Infraspinatus).
questions.hint: Injury to the group of muscles that help lift and rotate the arm.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by degenerative changes in the intervertebral discs, leading to narrowing of the disc space and osteophyte formation?
questions.explanation: Spondylosis is the general term for age-related degeneration (osteoarthritis) of the spine.
questions.hint: The general medical term for spinal arthritis/degeneration.

questions.question: A patient presents with acute pain, swelling, and deformity of the ankle following a twisting injury. X-ray reveals a fracture involving the distal fibula with associated widening of the ankle mortise. Which type of ankle fracture is most likely?
questions.explanation: Widening of the mortise indicates ligamentous instability often associated with complex fractures like a Trimalleolar fracture (involving medial, lateral, and posterior malleoli).
questions.hint: A complex fracture involving three parts of the ankle.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with Dupuytren's contracture?
questions.explanation: Dupuytren's contracture is frequently associated with other fibrotic conditions of the hand, such as stenosing tenosynovitis (Trigger Finger).
questions.hint: A condition where a finger gets stuck in a bent position.

questions.question: A patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with acute pain and swelling of the wrist joint. Physical examination reveals ulnar deviation of the fingers and swan-neck deformity of the digits. Which imaging modality is most appropriate for further evaluation?
questions.explanation: X-rays are the standard baseline imaging for RA to assess for bony erosions, joint space narrowing, and deformities.
questions.hint: The standard first look at bones for damage.

questions.question: A patient presents with knee pain and swelling following a fall onto a flexed knee. Physical examination reveals a palpable effusion and tenderness along the joint line. McMurray's test elicits pain and clicking. Which condition is most likely?
questions.explanation: A positive McMurray's test (pain/click with rotation and flexion) is a specific physical exam finding for meniscal tears.
questions.hint: The test involving clicking and rotation diagnoses this cartilage tear.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common complication associated with long-term corticosteroid use in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation: Long-term steroid use weakens bones significantly, making osteoporotic fractures the most common and generalized skeletal complication.
questions.hint: Weak bones lead to breaking bones.

questions.question: A patient with osteoarthritis of the hip undergoes surgical intervention with a total hip arthroplasty (THA). Which postoperative complication should the healthcare team monitor for in the immediate postoperative period?
questions.explanation: Venous Thromboembolism (DVT/PE) is a major risk after hip surgery due to immobility and vessel trauma. Prevention and monitoring are critical priorities.
questions.hint: A blood clot forming in the leg veins.
